def even_or_odd(number):
    return 'Odd' if number % 2 else 'Even'

def even_or_odd(number):
  return 'Even' if number % 2 == 0 else 'Odd'

def even_or_odd(number):
  return ["Even", "Odd"][number % 2]

def even_or_odd(number):
  # number % 2 will return 0 for even numbers and 1 for odd ones.
  # 0 evaluates to False and 1 to True, so we can do it with one line
  return "Odd" if number % 2 else "Even"

def even_or_odd(number):
  return 'Odd' if number & 1 else 'Even'
even_or_odd = lambda number: "Odd" if number % 2 else "Even"

  return number % 2 and 'Odd' or 'Even'

def even_or_odd(number):
    return ['Even','Odd'][number%2==1]

def even_or_odd(n):
    return "Odd" if n & 1 else "Even"

def even_or_odd(number):
    return ["Even","Odd"][float(number) /2 != int(number/2)]

# takes number
# returns "Even" for even numbers; "Odd" for odd numbers
def even_or_odd(number):
    return "Even" if number % 2 == 0 else "Odd"

def even_or_odd(number):
    a = int(number/2)
    if number/2 == a: return "Even"
    else: return "Odd"

def even_or_odd(number):
    if number % 2:     #any number above 0 is considered "True"
        return "Odd"   #so you can skip needing to do an equality check
    return "Even"
